HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 10, 1925

POSITIONS OFFERED
TO HOPKINS MEN
Business houses are anxious
to employ graduates of the
Hopkins College of Arts and
Sciences, according to Dr.
French, head of the Bureau
of Appointments.
"Requests," he said, "have
been made by several department stores, manufacturers,
and public service companies
that we put them in touch with
men who want regular positions now or after their graduation." He intimated that it
would be a good idea for Seniors in search of a job to call
at his office.

MUSICAL CLUB TO
GIVE DANSANTS
That the Musical Club will
sponsor two The Dansants, on
the afternoons of March 21
and 28, in the Civil Engineering Hall, was announced yesterday by R. C. Tilghman,
President of the Club. The
Blue Jay Orchestra will furnish the music for the affairs,
and will play directly after
giving their number at the
Maryland Theater, 'for the
first of the dances.
The dances on these two
Saturday9 will supercede the
usual Saturday night dance of
the Cotillon Club.

Announcement of the letting of
the contract for the new World
War Memorial Gymnasium at
Virginia Polytechnic Institute was
made recently. The building,
which is to cost approximately
$325,000, is being erected through
contributions made by alumni and
friends of the college and in all
probability will be finished within
a year. Besides housing a gymnasium the hall will be a general
students activities building and
will include rooms for the various
literary societies, offices for •the
college publication, rooms for
visiting teams and alumni and
last but not least a swimming
pool.

Baseball which is now getting
under way at the various colleges
and universities is occupying the
limelight in the sporting world.
One of the largest squads in
several years responded to Coach
Clarke's call at Princeton last
week, and practice for the 1925
season was begun. Fairly good
material is on hand but there is
a marked lack of substitutes in
case of injury to any regular member of the team.

POSITIONS OFFERED
TO HOPKINS MEN
Business houses are anxious
to employ graduates of the
Hopkins College of Arts and
Sciences, according to Dr.
French, head of the Bureau
of Appointments.
"Requests," he said, "have
been made by several department stores, manufacturers,
and public service companies
that we put them in touch with
men who want regular positions now or after their graduation." He intimated that it
would be a good idea for Seniors in search of a job to call
at his office.

MUSICAL CLUB TO
GIVE DANSANTS
That the Musical Club will
sponsor two The Dansants, on
the afternoons of March 21
and 28, in the Civil Engineering Hall, was announced yesterday by R. C. Tilghman,
President of the Club. The
Blue Jay Orchestra will furnish the music for the affairs,
and will play directly after
giving their number at the
Maryland Theater, 'for the
first of the dances.
The dances on these two
Saturday9 will supercede the
usual Saturday night dance of
the Cotillon Club.

Announcement of the letting of
the contract for the new World
War Memorial Gymnasium at
Virginia Polytechnic Institute was
made recently. The building,
which is to cost approximately
$325,000, is being erected through
contributions made by alumni and
friends of the college and in all
probability will be finished within
a year. Besides housing a gymnasium the hall will be a general
students activities building and
will include rooms for the various
literary societies, offices for •the
college publication, rooms for
visiting teams and alumni and
last but not least a swimming
pool.

Baseball which is now getting
under way at the various colleges
and universities is occupying the
limelight in the sporting world.
One of the largest squads in
several years responded to Coach
Clarke's call at Princeton last
week, and practice for the 1925
season was begun. Fairly good
material is on hand but there is
a marked lack of substitutes in
case of injury to any regular member of the team.
